ratings.comment: He is a good lecturer but I feel he expects students to understand a lot of implied or underlying concepts, theorems, etc (even from previous classes!) and won't care to explain them in lecture. If you are a good mathematician (and good with proofs) then he will be good for you, but for those that require an extra push I do not recommend

honestly, while simon marshall may come off as rude, i can tel he means well and cares for his students. His style of teaching personally didn't work with me, but I ended up doing well in the class anyway

Same complaints as all other reviews.
In addition he was very unhelpful during office hours, would only tell students what part of their answer was wrong and then move onto the next student. He also grades very strictly: his midterms are graded with partial credit however he will take points off for something wrong.
I didn't mind his lectures but he was very strict on grading and gave no partial credit
Play it safe and pick a different professor
To say he is a strict grader is an understatement. He is unnecessarily strict, and I found that he took points off homework on things that were closer to technicalities than inaccuracies/mistakes.

He did say after our first hw he wasn't afraid to fail half the class, and by the end about half the class dropped the class. The lesson learned is don't underestimate this class. I got an A in Math 341, so I thought I'd be fine jumping to this class - I would highly recommend NOT doing that. It is an interesting class though, as it's very formal.
hard course made harder by this professor. Would not recommend to anyone

Great lecturer. Clear, provides examples, answers questions  
But:
-claimed there was partial credit on midterm, but next lecture he said he made first 2 pages no partial credit
-strict grader: half points off on questions for one inaccuracy despite the rest of the proof being correct
"I am not afraid to fail half the class"

Would not recommend

Prof. Marshall is one of my favorite math professors. Math 521 isn't an easy course yet he does a great job of helping students conceptualize very abstract math concepts. He's a tough grader on homework and tests but feedback was given and overall helped build my mathematical confidence. Finally, he is very helpful and willing to answer questions.

He has a fun accent, is accessible outside of class, is a clear lecturer, and is a hard grader. He doesn't give away answers but will provide hints. The tests are very fair. He goes pretty slow in lectures, so there is time to absorb the material.

As someone with little background in proofs, this course required effort outside of class and in office hours. He explains concepts very clearly and coherently, but sometimes glosses over points that he (and other more advanced students) just assume. He doesn't give straight answers but is good at leading students to figure out the answer.

Simon is clear, he answers questions well, and he doesn't assign too much work. The lectures mostly just go over the proofs from the readings in more detail, so if you read the assigned reading and understand it, you don't really need to go to class (but it's still fun to). Make some friends in the class and do the homework together.

Professor Marshall wasted a lot of time in class going over topics he found interesting rather than what was on tests. Then when test time came he was very rigorous about proof standards he refused to elaborate on. Getting him to answer a direct question was nearly impossible at times.

Marshall is a good professor. He is knowledgable, and always talks about some important points and then lists some exercises and helps students to understand or figure out them one on one. The exams are not too difficult, but Marshall deducts points relatively harshly if there is a little mistake in your proof. Overall not a bad experience.
Best Maths Prof I've seen, caring, friendly and enthusiastic.

lecture is a waste of time, I never had any idea what he was talking about, he was either going over pointless proofs or spending hours on the easiest topics. TAs are super important in this class, use homework and discussion sheets to study. I probably wouldn't have done as well if I hadn't already taken calc in high school with an amazing teacher

Honestly I think this guy is an expert in math but he is not a good teacher any way. I still remembered that when I asked him certain basic concepts in the last part of the semester, he kinda forced me to memorize the proof of that thing in front of a few students in his office. It could be one of the most shameful moments in my sophomore year.

Simon is very intelligible on the topic he is teaching, however it is almost as though he is too intelligent to teach it. He is unable to break it down to an understandable level. Tests are 84% of the grade and there are only 2 other than the final. I had an easy A in calculus in high school and am struggling to receive a B in Math 222.

Lectures were often filled with unnecessary proofs, but homework and exams were fair and he made his expectations clear. TAs were helpful and discussion was useful for understanding the material. Not the most interesting lecturer, but Simon provides you with what you need to understand Calc 1.
Simon is definitely a solid choice of professor for this course. His TAs are also very kind and capable. Worksheets are very helpful and well written. Good vides in the classroom!
Good guy. Smart guy. Not the most engaging or concise lecturer.
Cool guy. Meh professor. Goes on and on about unnecessary proofs and theorems. Like for a long time. Not the best at explaining concepts, but not the absolute worst.

I would not recommend taking Calc 1 with Professor Marshall. He is a tough grader and he does not give much partial credit on exams. His lectures are boring and he constantly talks about proofs that are not required for the exams. He makes intro calc more confusing than it needs to be (I took AP Calc in high school and I was more confused at UW).
Solid choice for a professor, one of my favorites in the Math Department at UW-Madison

Simon literally would just sit in front of the class and test proofs the whole time. Going to lecture is a waste of your time. Kahn is the man, but seriously this course is very hard if you have not taken Calculus before. Retaking is with a different professor and she is 100 times better.

Took his class for Math 221. He spent a lot of the first half of the semester writing out proofs which were unnecessary and did not help with understanding how to do the problems. He got better towards the end. Tests were very easy and the class overall wasn't too bad.

The guy knows his stuff. He has a nice New Zealand accent to listen to, even though his lectures are a bit boring (but what math class isn't?). You won't get to use a calculator on tests or quizzes, but the math is simple enough to do in your head or on paper. The tests come directly from course materiel so don't expect something you've never seen.

Very intelligent, but not a good teacher unless you have at least some background with calc. Many of his lectures were theory based and would go off on tangents to complete proofs that weren't relevant to the material. Tests were fairly easy if you understand the worksheets given in discussions but make sure all work on tests is shown clearly.
Worst math teacher ever. Says he'll curve the class but doesn't in the end. Lectures are super boring and pointless. Doesn't explain what he's doing or how he got there. Would not recommend.

Simon speaks good English and he can get all the topics across to you. He isn't amazing by any means but you can definitely do well in the class with this professor. He spends an annoying amount of lecture time on theory and proving why a rule works, but his tests are overall fair. I will say that the grading did seem harsh at times.

Simon Marshall is a smart individual and knows what he is talking about. I find his lectures to be very theory based as well as his tests. I, personally have had calculus in high school so I didn't think the course was too rigorous. He does use the textbook and posts his notes online.

Professor Marshall is not the greatest math professor. If you have not taken prior calculus classes, his class will be near impossible unless you spend hours outside of class with your TA or watching lots of Khan Academy. The lectures make no sense and he does not give lots of useful help when you need it. Choose him if you want a challenge.

When you go to his office hours he is pretty helpful, but in his lectures he doesn't answer questions or tells people to see him after class. He is kind of intimidating, but can be funny. His tests are nice because the practice tests are about the same length or less than the actual thing, but sometimes just as hard.  You also get to drop 2 quizes.
Boring lectures. Grading is ridiculous, takes off points for showing too much work.

He was terrible. His lectures make absolutely no sense, if I hadn't taken Calculus in high school I would have struggled so much. You might as well not even go to lecture if he is your professor because you won't understand anything he is talking about. I would definitely advise to avoid having him as your professor.

If I had not taken calculus in high school, this class would likely be impossible with Prof Marshall. His lectures are very unclear, and he is not good at explaining his methods. Don't bother buying the notes as they are online and don't help anyway. Ask questions during discussion because others are probably just as confused as you.

His lectures tend to be quite unclear and very proof-heavy. At times it is difficult to follow the steps he is taking when giving examples, and sort of expects that everyone in the class already has an idea of the topics he is covering. That being said, the tests are quite fair and if you put in the work outside of lecture you will be fine.

He teaches math 221 or first-semester calculus. Beware. This class is terrible without previous calculus classes. Many people in the class have taken calc AB or BC in high school and still struggle. He teaches like everyone already knows whats going on, so if you're like me with nothing but precalc, get ready for the worst semester.
Awesome guy

Half the time I have no idea what he's talking about- his lecture notes are all over the place and he doesn't give enough examples for some of the harder topics. He also has a tendency to move on in the material even though half the class doesn't understand what was just covered. He also doesn't answer everyone's questions.

After doing pretty poorly in 221, I was terrified of 222. I found that Simon made difficult material easier to understand. He is good at explaining and if you pay attention and put in the effort outside of class it is very possible to do well. Quizzes/worksheets/class examples help a lot when studying for exams and hw is graded on completion.
Explains material very well in lecture. Clear on what he expects of students. Very fair.

Real analysis is a tough class, but Simon teaches it very well.  He explains examples and clarifies if you ask, although sometimes might talk down to you (probably because he's so smart).  He also tells some pretty weird jokes, but only once in a while, so they're usually gems.  Overall, he helped me understand the proofs extremely well.
Good guy. Means well. Does not teach effectively whatsoever. His notes are all over the place. One thing i liked about him in particular is his ability to speak english. Thats always a bonus

So math 521 is a very hard class no matter who you take it with. Marshall at least is a very organized and clear lecturer. The homework is tough, but the tests aren't as difficult as the homework (still study a lot!). The final is cumulative so keep refreshing the material.
Great class overall, it's a tough class but he's an outstanding lecturer.
